h1: Accessibility statement for Apply for New Style ESA
p1: This service is part of the wider GOV.UK website. There's a separate accessibility statement for the main GOV.UK website.
p2: This page only contains information about the Apply for New Style Employment and Support Allowance (ESA) service, available at https://www.apply-new-style-employment-support-allowance.dwp.gov.uk

usingThisService.p1: This service is run by the Department for Work and Pensions. We want as many people as possible to be able to use this service. For example, that means you should be able to:
usingThisService.li1: change colours, contrast levels and fonts
usingThisService.li2: zoom in up to 300% without the text spilling off the screen
usingThisService.li3: get from the start of the service to the end using just a keyboard
usingThisService.li4: get from the start of the service to the end using speech recognition software
usingThisService.li5: listen to the service using a screen reader
usingThisService.p2: We've also made the text in the service as simple as possible to understand.
usingThisService.p3: AbilityNet has advice on making your device easier to use if you have a disability.

howAccessibleThisServiceIs.p1: The service is using common styles, patterns and components from the GOV.UK Design System which are widely regarded as accessible.
howAccessibleThisServiceIs.p2: Some people may find parts of this service difficult to use:
howAccessibleThisServiceIs.li1: at one point we ask you to list your conditions using a JavaScript solution that allows you to keep adding additional fields. This can be tricky. However, with JavaScript turned off the service will default to a large amount of blank fields which some people might find easier to fill out
howAccessibleThisServiceIs.li2: if you say “new tab” to some voice control software, it opens the feedback link instead of opening a new tab
howAccessibleThisServiceIs.li3: on the bank details page, the fields do not allow white space. This causes an error if you use voice control software and pause when reading out your account number
howAccessibleThisServiceIs.li4: error messages are sometimes not read out in JAWS versions 18 and 19
howAccessibleThisServiceIs.li5: headings are sometimes not read out in JAWS versions 18 and 19 and ZoomText. This is a known issue with Freedom Scientific software. Read more about the issue with headings on GitHub
howAccessibleThisServiceIs.li6: text is sometimes repeated by ZoomText‘s DocReader and SpeakIt tools
howAccessibleThisServiceIs.li7: reading zones sometimes move around the page when scrolling with ZoomText. This might cause a problem with the consent question pages, as well as the ‘check your answers’ and ‘what happens next’ pages, where there is lots of text

difficultyUsingService.h2: What to do if you have difficulty using this service
difficultyUsingService.p1: If you have difficulty using this service, contact us by email: applyfornewstyleesa.accessibility@dwp.gov.uk
difficultyUsingService.p2: As part of providing this service, we may need to send you messages or documents. We'll ask you how you want us to send messages or documents to you, but contact us if you need them in a different format. For example large print, audio recording or braille.

reportingAccessibilityProblems.h2: Reporting accessibility problems with this service
reportingAccessibilityProblems.p1: We're always looking to improve the accessibility of this service. If you find any problems that are not listed on this page or think we're not meeting accessibility requirements, contact us by email: applyfornewstyleesa.accessibility@dwp.gov.uk

enforcementProcedure.p1: The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) is responsible for enforcing the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018 (the 'accessibility regulations'). If you're not happy with how we respond to your complaint, contact the Equality Advisory and Support Service (EASS).

technicalInformationAboutServiceAccessib.h2: Technical information about this service's accessibility
technicalInformationAboutServiceAccessib.p1: The Department for Work and Pensions is committed to making this service accessible, in accordance with the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018.
technicalInformationAboutServiceAccessib.p2: This service is fully compliant with the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines version 2.1 AA standard.

howWeTested.p1: The service was last tested on 28 May 2020 and was checked for compliance with WCAG 2.1 AA. The tests were carried out by the Department for Work and Pensions.
howWeTested.p2: The service was tested using both automated and manual testing.

improveAccessibility.h2: What we're doing to improve accessibility
improveAccessibility.p1: We conducted manual testing of the service using assistive technologies such as JAWS and Dragon. This has identified issues, mentioned in the ‘using this service’ section above, that we’re working to fix.
improveAccessibility.p2: We will continue to iterate the design of the service, replacing the JavaScript solution for adding conditions to make it more usable.
improveAccessibility.p3: This page was prepared on 14 April 2020 and last updated on 3 August 2020.
